subject: Spell check on commit message support for CI
commitMessage:
Spell check on commit message support for CI

- This commit would add the codespell package while
  building the base container.

- The intention is that, we maintain two dictionaries
  1. That comes directly with codespell
    - We should also download the latest dictionary while
      while building the base container.
  2. An openbmc spellings dictionary
    - We should be able to add words and spellings that are
      openbmc related in this dictionary over time.

- When the commit message have words that the dictionary does not have,
the CI proceeds further without any rejection. The CI only scores a -1 if
it sees a word wrongly spelled from it knowledge from the dictionary.

Tested by:

1. when commit message have mistakes: It breaks & scores a -1
   It also highlights the spelling mistake and the correct spelling
   to be used.

2. when commit message does not have mistakes : it does not break &
   proceeds further for compilation.

Signed-off-by: Manojkiran Eda <manojkiran.eda@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I87278597876b6e2b0a59e297cde020631491b5fd

Patch Set 1:

Do other projects do this?  The thing that worries me is now having to go update our custom dictionary in another repository when we want to use some technical jargon in our commit message that isn't already in a dictionary introducing more dependencies.

Patch Set 1: -Ok-To-Test

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Do other projects do this?  The thing that worries me is now having to go update our custom dictionary in another repository when we want to use some technical jargon in our commit message that isn't already in a dictionary introducing more dependencies.

Yes, as far as investigated Linux project uses similar thing, and also redfish has a similar thing too.That does not work how you are expecting , because the dictionary that we proposed is not a traditional one(please look at dictionary/openbmc-spelling.txt in this commit), the CI only marks a -1 when it is sees a wrong spelling of a word that is already added into the dictionary, if the word is NOT present in the mistakes dictionary at all , then it will not complain.

I have already added most of the mistakes that we tend to do (thanks to linux developers), this does not add any more dependencies at all.
Removed reviewer Gunnar Mills.
Removed reviewer Ed Tanous.

Patch Set 1:

So a few options to get this to pass CI:
- Change jenkins/run-build-script-ci to run the format-code.sh within a docker container
- Check within format-code.sh for the needed spellcheck app and just continue if not found
- Remove format-code.sh from jenkins/run-build-script-ci

The second one is probably my favorite at this point. We wont get spellcheck on commits to this repo but all the other repos would. We could come back at a later date and work on number 1.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as e6f120aaacd1c70cd8ec5c6a95ada03e9c922af8 by Andrew Geissler

Can you talk through in your commit message the behavior when we see things that the dictionary doesn't have in it?

For example SAS is probably not in any dictionary, but is perfectly valid in OpenBMC and the industry.  Would this commit reject it, and require a second commit to go update the dictionary?  Or does it only adjust for common spelling mistakes?

Updated the commit message.

> For example SAS is probably not in any dictionary, but is perfectly valid in OpenBMC and the industry.  Would this commit reject it, and require a second commit to go update the dictionary?  Or does it only adjust for common spelling mistakes?

No, CI does not reject in this case. The CI scores -1 only in case where it sees a word that is wrongly spelled from what is present in the dictionary. It does not do anything when it sees a word that is not present in the dictionary.
Cool.  Sounds good to me.
I'm confused on this one, this was passing before wasn't it?

It worked in the beginning , but hit with his error in my latest patches.

+ cd /home/jenkins-op/workspace/CI-MISC/ci-openbmc-build-scripts/openbmc-build-scripts
+ ./scripts/format-code.sh .
Formatting code under ./
./scripts/format-code.sh: line 51: shellcheck: command not found
ok, must depend on which CI system the job gets assigned to, more motivation to get this into a docker container.

Does anything here actually fail?  Just printing a message isn't going to be useful because nobody will look at the Jenkins logs.

How do we deal with the two dictionaries?  A word might be missing from one but in another?

Are we choosing UK or US spellings on words?  Maybe that is decided by the locale?

> Does anything here actually fail?  Just printing a message isn't going to be useful because nobody will look at the Jenkins logs.

Yes, it does fail and that is caused by the "set -e" command that is placed in the top of this script.

> How do we deal with the two dictionaries?  A word might be missing from one but in another?

Yes, as time goes I am expecting people in the openbmc community to add the mistakes that they observe in the reviews to the openbmc-spelling.txt file.And the other one is the dictionary which is provided by the code spell package, so its quite possible that we can have a word in one dictionary that might be missing in other.

> Are we choosing UK or US spellings on words?  Maybe that is decided by the locale?

I am not sure of this, the dictionary that comes by the codespell library via pip package manager, i think locale is a good guess, let me search more.

In-case you missed, i have sent this proposal to the mailing list 
https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/CAFe7vzSvFt7bpAGz9u+vH42RQd9vPEQ_1pvi-1UNDJXMdOAPrQ@mail.gmail.com/
Unfortunately this silently skips if shellcheck is not found.  Can we split this part into a separate commit and print a message for it?  (same with the spell check above)

This was only done because this script is run even before the base container was build, so these packages will not be present. This is just a work around for now, but i can change it based on your suggestion.

Fixed here so that the tools run under the Docker instance in all cases, including against this repository.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/+/41719
Sure, i rebased my commit on top of yours.

It appears that we could make a single call to `codespell` by using both the --dictionary (-D) option and --builtin.  I asked before about en_GB spellings and it does look like there is a `en-GB_to-en-US` builtin we could enable.  The default builtin dictionary uses US spellings, but doesn't try to correct non-US spellings (ex. colour is valid).  I'm not sure how people feel about that one way or the other.

Thanks for the inputs. No -D <dictionary> & --builtin are mutually exclusive. we can't search in both the dictionaries in a single call.
 
» codespell --builtin clear,rare,en-GB_to_en-US -d --count .git/COMMIT_EDITMSG                                                                                 
.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG:3: sertificate ==> certificate
.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG:4: acknowledgement ==> acknowledgment
.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG:5: colour ==> color
3

» codespell -D ../openbmc-build-scripts/dictionary/openbmc-spelling.txt --builtin clear,rare,en-GB_to_en-US -d --count .git/COMMIT_EDITMSG        
.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG:4: acknowledgement ==> acknowledgment
1

It looks like when -D option is mentioned, it does not check the builtin dictionary from code spell, but it uses the openbmc-spelling.txt , but when i removed the -D option ,and used the --builtin option with en-GB_to-en_US , that seems to indicate the non-US spellings.

> I'm not sure how people feel about that one way or the other.

u mean, we picking US over UK spellings ? can we just pick US and move forward ?
